description:
A board game about the GREAT city of Raleigh! We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some awesome parks, higher education, the arts, a great big acorn, and some BIG FUN... and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; Raleigh-OPOLY! Grab Some Friends and Gather 'Round!

Here's a quick idea of how to play! Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!

Get YOUR Game On, Raleigh! It's Your Roll!

Publisher's Website

We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some culture, awesome fiestas, Tex-Mex, a great big Alamo, some BIG FUN... and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; San Antonio-OPOLY! Grab Some Friends and Gather 'Round!

Here's a quick idea of how to play! Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!

Get YOUR Game On, San Antonio! It’s Your Roll!

Publisher's Website

A board game about the GREAT city of Santa Fe! We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some majestic mountains, beautiful pueblos, the arts, a world-famous opera, and some BIG FUN... and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; SANTA FE-OPOLY! Grab Some Friends and Gather 'Round!
 Here's a quick idea of how to play! Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!
 Get YOUR Game On, Santa Fe! It's Your Roll!

Publisher's Website

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

This is a re-themed version of Monopoly sporting St Louis Landmarks.

From the description of the game:
"When war comes, humans no longer man the battlefield. Wars are fought by mechs, giant robots, remotely controlled from far-away bases, with the riders of these giant mechs completely out of harms way.

Nonetheless, your commanding officers have a job for you. A job putting you in the line of real danger. Intel suggests that the enemy has amassed a large force, and put them ashore outside your capital in the midst of night. Their mission? To launch nuclear missiles at your nations leader, and every monument in your capital.

Our engineers have sent out a signal that interrupts the mech's connection with their home base, causing them to wander meanlessly around.

Now, you must sneak out to destroy each of the enemies' mechs, before they are powered up and ready to launch.But be careful."

Sneak Attack is a free, print-to-play game designed for the "sneaky sci-fi game contest".
During play, you will move around a hexagonal board depicting a battlefield. The player will attempt to sneak up on enemy mechs, destroying them with EMP charges, in order to save their home, and the pride of their country.

From the Publishers website:
When Peter Parker, bitten by radioactive spider, he received a spider's relative speed, force and movement. He became Spider-Man. 
Such amazing talents like to hang the web and climb the walls, he used to fight against crime.
Now Spider-Man is in danger of losing his power to his secret enemies. The radioactive spider has disappeared from his dark secret laboratory. 
Now all the Spider-Man disguised enemies are terrorizing the New York. They all are now more dangerous than ever, because now they hold the key to Spider-Mans power.
The only way to cope with precarious situation and restore order to New York is to find the radioactive spider and take it to security, a secret laboratory.
Your task is not easy, because all the players will try to find the missing spider. 
During the game you need to survive action events and traps, you also have to fight against other players. Who is the right and true Spider-Man? It will not become clear until the very end of the game. Right Spider-Man is the one who succeeds in bringing the radioactive spider back to the laboratory.

Content: Board
  1 dice
  1 Spider-Man spinner
  6 Spider-Man character (pawn)
  6 colored tripod pawns
  5 reels
  sticker sheet with 5 stickers
  50 cards (14 Syndicate Cards, 12 Surprise Cards, 24 Accessory Cards)

There are many cards, each card has 6 words written on it. Each word has a number, from 1 to 6. Words are various - from very easy to very hard. Some are made of several words defining one thing (example: "Silver Medal"). There is also a board with tiles. Each tile is marked with number from 1 to 6.

So, players play 2 vs.2. Each team gets a figure representing it on the board. Their goal is to get through the board. Each time a figure stops one team member must take a card and not show it to other team member. After that a sand clock (also included) is set. The Player must get the other team member to say the word that is written on card by using sentences to describe the word. For example, if the word is "Silver Medal", a player can say "something that a sportsmen wins at the Olympic games". But if other team member says just "Medal", it isn't correct. Then the first player must further define what the hint might be. Second player can answer as often as he/she wants until the time runs out. If time runs out or first player accidentally uses the word which is written in card, the team looses a turn.

In this Genius Alias, you have word you have never heard. The are long, they are hard. Are you smart enough to play this game???

Japanese CCG created by Bandai and based on the pocket digital pet and anime series of the same name. Known as Digimon in the US.

Players pit various monsters against eachother in battle, attempting to deplete the opponents of energy and striving to evolve their own monsters to more powerful forms by playing cards to enhance combat or advance the monsters through two or more stages.

Each monster is denoted by a leter and colour type that is referenced vs the opponents monster to determine one of three types of attacks that can be performed. Players attempt to outperform their opponent by playing enhancements to increase the power of the attack, evolve to a more potent form, or to even change the colour type to one more advantageous. Cards may also be played to weaken or devolve the opponent monsters.
The monster ending the battle with the highest rating wins.

Each starter contains 34 cards and one gold embossed card and one special "hologram" card. Rules and battlemat are combined in a single mapfold sheet.

The Upper Deck release of the Digimon game in 2000 appears to use slightly modified cards as this with similar rules.

Issue game of old Game Journal 48. Covers the whole story of the first TV series of Space Cruiser Yamato.

The basic mechanics is Mille Bornes.

The first player to go Iscandal and bring back Cosmo-cleaner to the Earth is the winner. If no player can bring back the Cosmo-cleaner within the determined number of decks, the earth would be lost.

1 timetrack
108 cards

A skirmish miniatures game of pirate combat!  The game consists of a rulebook, illustrated cards with stats for the figures, and miniature figures, sold separately.

From the publisher's description of the rulebook:

The rulebook, published separately in German and English, contains all the rules you need to play Freebooter's Fate as well as the complete list of all the crews. Plus a bunch of scenarios for you to play, a splendid piece of cover art by Paul Bonner, pictures of all available miniatures for the game, concept art, valuable advice, cracking background stories and even a shanty if you fancy some hearty musical accompaniment to your actions.

Get the game, grab a mate, have a go. You'll love it. How could you not? It's got everything! Rapacious pirates! Grog-swilling goblins! Mysterious assassins! Steadfast Imperials! Merciless mercenaries! Parrots! A cast of knaves, villains, heroes, ladies, and wenches with guns. With a thousand peg legs.

116 pages, softcover.

And of the cards:

These cards are at the root of Freebooter's Fate. The pack comprises 40 fate cards with numbers and symbols, two sets of 6 hit location cards each and a set of 12 event cards. You will need this pack to play the game, but you will only need one pack for a game, regardless of the number of players and characters involved.

The cards are bilingual where appropriate, so you only need this pack, regardless of which version of the rulebook you use (German or English).

Powerrails is an 18xx game which uses no regional setting like other games of the series, but eleven small (A4-sized) mapboards with only a handful of hexes and a small set of special rules for each of them.

The players are seeking to make the most money by buying and selling stock certificates of up to eight railroad companies (depending on the scenario played). The player with the most stock of a particular company in his possession acts as the president of this company and is responsible for track laying, the placement of railheads (which are necessary for train runs), route selection and train acquisition. Running trains earns money and this money is either divided by the shareholders or kept in the company's treasure for further investments (like buying better trains or constructing track). This decision influences the value of the company's shares - and not the player with the most stock or the most beautiful constructed track wins the game, but the player with the most riches in terms of cash and shares.

The subtitle on the box is "Quickies for 1830 players". It uses mostly elements from 1830 and 1835, but introduces two new features: There is a ‘purple phase’ after the ‘grey phase’, and the ‘grey phase’ introduces city tiles with only one token space (tokens from the replaced brown tiles are all returned to their respective owning companies for future use).

All maps are playable in 2 to 4 hours, and most of them are especially tested for a 2-player game (in case of a 2-player game, the usual 60% holding limit in a company is lifted, if you buy additional shares from the bank pool).

Set in the far future, where the innocent are arrested for mere thoughts, one man is making a break for freedom. Players take control of the innocent man and his hacker friend and work together to outfox the automated prison guards and weapon systems.

A single board represents both the physical jail and the equivalent cyber world. As the heros move around the board they collect information in the form of cards that can be played to disable the jails defences, thereby making it easier to reach the goal

As well as fixed on-board obstructions the player has to avoid or deal with game controlled robots that move and patrol the jail.

Mission Patrol is a game that is played with card tiles that you withdraw and roll dice to determine your fate. Your mission to find the detonator & charger in the jungle of Kimono island and destroy the man eating infested monsters island. The timer's ticking so hurry and reach for the chopper and escape to win the game. This game is designed to be played by 1 player. Good Luck Lieutenant Gimp.

Adventures in the Lost Lands is a tabletop miniature wargame based on the Two-Hour Wargames' Chain Reaction system.  It provides rules for gaming with dinosaurs, mammalian mega-fauna, and other prehistoric creatures in a variety of eras and settings.
 From the website:

Adventures in the Lost Lands introduces you to a world like no other, a world of giant creatures and prehistoric men where you can:

-Be a Pulp Era hero exploring lost lands and searching for valuable treasure
-Lead your tribe of primitive cavemen in a fight against other primitive tribes
-Be a modern-day big game hunter who travels to a prehistoric land that Time forgot
-Command a Victorian-era expedition bent on discovery and conquest
-Be a dinosaur (not only a dinosaur, but THE dinosaur), as you take on all others for supremacy
-Or maybe command a squad of WW 2 GIs hurled into a strange prehistoric world while on maneuvers in Louisiana (it's a long story....)

In Adventures in the Lost Lands, you can do all of this and more. We've included a number of linked scenarios forming a campaign that can be played solo, cooperatively with all players on the same side, or head-to-head against your friends. It's all up to you!

Adventures in the Lost Lands is a stand-alone game that can also be used with Larger Than Life and other Two-Hour Wargames rules.

Description from the rulebook

Bloodlines is a game that can be played by 2-6 players. Each player controls one bloodline, which is represented by a set of nobles from the same family tree. Each living noble has one or two genetic markers, indicating which (up to two) bloodlines he or she belongs to. The genetic markers appear as tokens on the noble’s card.
The game proceeds in turns, and in each turn, the player can perform a set of actions with one or more of the nobles in his bloodline (nobles containing at least one marker for the players bloodline). Actions include having a baby, getting married, starting an affair, or challenging another noble to a duel.
Your goal is to use your actions wisely to build the most powerful bloodline in the game.

A Warpspawn game simulating the emergence - and rapid disappearance - of "vice towns" as the Union Pacific Railroad was laying down tracks in the 1860's to link the east and west coasts of the USA.  Each of 2-6 players bids to become RR Supervisor, who controls the order of activities in that turn, then spends their filthy lucre to build civilized establishments (schools, post offices) that bring in tax money and "other" establishments (saloons, gambling halls) that bring in more filthy lucre if they have lots of customers and mayhem. The game was just made available by Lloyd Krassner's Warpspawn Games, rules available on the Warpspawn website and e-group.

Fancy Nancy themed game. Players take turns Spinning the spinner to collect at least three different flavors of ice cream in their dish then top it off with a cherry. The spinner has the 4 different ice cream flavors spots, two cherry spots, an Oops! spot, and a Switch a Scoop spot. 
Players begin with an empty dish. Play begins with the person wearing pink hearts or the youngest. The player spins the spinner, if it lands on a flavor they do not have they get to put that flavor on their dish, if they already have that flavor, play goes to next player, an Oops! the player must put an ice cream back, a Switch a Scoop lets the player switch a scoop with another player, a cherry lets the player pick a flavor they wish or to put a cherry on their dish if they have 3 different ice cream flavors. The goal is to be the first to have a complete parfait.
Recommended for 2-4 players age 4 and up.
Helps teach turn taking, color recognition and very simple strategy to block another player with the Switch a Scoop. No reading is needed.
Contents:
Spinner
20 scoops of ice cream (cardboard)
4 cherries (cardboard)
4 fancy parfait dishes (cardboard)
1 play mat
-user submitted

The galaxy has been a peaceful place for many years. After the ruthless Terran–Hegemony War (30.027–33.364), much effort has been employed by all major spacefaring species to prevent the terrifying events from repeating themselves. The Galactic Council was formed to enforce precious peace, and it has taken many courageous efforts to prevent the escalation of malicious acts. Nevertheless, tension and discord are growing among the seven major species and in the Council itself. Old alliances are shattering, and hasty diplomatic treaties are made in secrecy. A confrontation of the superpowers seems inevitable – only the outcome of the galactic conflict remains to be seen. Which faction will emerge victorious and lead the galaxy under its rule?

A game of Eclipse places you in control of a vast interstellar civilization, competing for success with its rivals. You will explore new star systems, research technologies, and build spaceships with which to wage war. There are many potential paths to victory, so you need to plan your strategy according to the strengths and weaknesses of your species, while paying attention to the other civilizations' endeavors.

The shadows of the great civilizations are about to eclipse the galaxy. Lead your people to victory!

1970 Robin Hood boardgame by Editrice Giochi. The game included a 3d representation of the Sherwood Forest, along with a part of the Nottingham castle.

Players have to actually shoot the Nottingham Sheriff figure which walks through the forest. Four small firing crossbows are included in the game.

The game was marketed by Editrice Giochi as a "3Dimensional Game", because of the Sherwood forest setting which has actually to be built before playing.

Dragon Rampage, a competitive fantasy game by Richard Launius, is a strategic dice game for 3 to 5 players. Each player takes the role of one of the adventurers (all with different abilities) and the goal is to score the most points at the end of the game by fighting against or running from (or some combination of the two) the dragon you just woke up, and tallying up the treasure and gold you obtain in the dungeon. Players roll seven specially designed dice and choose whether to focus on grabbing treasure (from the dragon or from another player), fighting the dragon, protecting themselves (and their treasure), or running for the exit. Try not to draw the dragon's attention as you make your way, and note that your fellow adventurers may hinder (or aid) you in your strategy and the final scoring varies depending on how the game ends, so watch your step!

The contents of Dragon Rampage is:

1 rulebook

1 game board
6 character mats

30 hero wound tokens (red crystals)
1 first player token
1 re-roll token
8 dice

72 dragon wound cubes (12 per player)
54 hero action tokens (9 per player)
6 player movement tokens (1 per player)

128 cards:

     24 dragon rampage cards
     32 treasure cards
     72 hero character cards (12 per hero)


50 coin tokens:

     20 5-value coins
     30 1-value coins

"The game of playing it safe... while walking, bicycling, and driving."

Teaches children to use their eyes before their feet as they move tokens around a street grid. The crossing guard tokens helps the children and the game also teaches kids to avoid talking to strangers.

Situations include crossing at a traffic light, dialing 911, and hitchhiking.

Includes a colorful board with a spinner, kid tokens, car tokens, rules, and a sheet of reflective stickers for children to put on their bikes.

Cardinal Item No. 7000

User summary: When more than three play, the players form teams.

Each card represents a number of electoral votes. To win the card (and get the votes) a player must roll the number on the card on either die or total of both dice. A player who gets the plurality of votes in a state wins the entire state. The player (or team) that gets the plurality of electoral votes has won the game.

Humanity has made the jump to the stars only to find that they are not alone.  We are threatened by pirates, aliens and danger at every turn.  Our only hope is to send 2-4 intrepid heroes into the unknown to find new technology that might turn the tide in earth's favor.

Players take on the role of Earth's last hope, charting the galaxy, discovering new worlds and making a profit on the side. Keep an eye out for the four mysterious alien races: The Heartiols, The Diamondias, The Clubstations and The Spadoo. These fantastic beings have harnessed the power to 'spin' their region of space and will impart that power to you, for a price.  With this power, the Human race can effectively turn away any invader that might threaten the Earth.  Only a hero with all four space spinning artifacts can save us!

Playable with 4 space tiles, player ship tracking boards some tokens and a deck of standard playing cards!

From USAopoly.com:

Buy, sell and trade your way to victory. Visit Schrute Farms and spend a night in the cozy "closet room". Get into the scent aroma market by acquiring Serenity by Jan. If you like "cable readiness" and paper thin walls, then be sure to invest in Michael’s condo.

Make deals and trades while building your corporate empire. Stay sharp because there is only room for one at the top. . . that’s what she said.

Game comes complete with six unique collectible tokens chosen by fans featuring - Dwight bobblehead, Pam’s candy dish, Beet, Unicorn princess, World’s Best Boss coffee mug and Bacon grill.

From USAopoly.com:

Saddle up for an adventure with the Duke!

Celebrate the life and career of one of the most beloved actors of our time, John Wayne. Known best for his roles as a cowboy, he also was a great athlete, rancher and outdoorsman representing the adventurous spirit of America.

As you attempt to bankrupt your opponents by buying, selling and trading the most significant properties in John Wayne’s life, kindly heed these words:

"You can take everything a man has as long as you leave him his dignity." -- John Wayne

Includes six collectible tokens: Cowboy Hat, Belt Buckle, Cowboy Boot, "Duke" the dog, John Wayne’s Director's Chair and Stagecoach.

Crystal Formation is an Icehouse game for 2-4 players played on a chessboard.
Each player is given all of one color pieces and starts with a tree of their color in their corner of the board.The piece represents a node.
During your turn,you may perform one of the following actions:
1.Place new nodes.
2.Increase the total power of a node.
3.Move a node.
First player with 5 trees on the board wins.

Based on the popular German TV series "Am laufenden Band", the boardgame version is fun for all in the family. Every player maneuvers his playing piece across a conveyor belt, aiming for the highest scoring playing fields. The players push their luck and have to jump off the conveyor belt at right time. Content: 1 playing board, 24 playing pieces, 1 dice, 1 rulebook.

Introduction

You drew the short straw on Space Ranger duty today - your Federation of Planets scout ship was assigned to Sneakius IV, the most dangerous planet in the entire universe.  And in keeping with your luck, your ship encountered a mysterious space storm and crashed!

Sneakius IV is crammed full of every kind of lethal predator and deadly parasite that you could imagine... and you'll have to use your imagination because no survey team has ever survived the onslaught of ravenous beasties to file a report.  Your only hope is to try to make it across unknown terrain past horrible monsters to an escape shuttle at the abandoned ecology survey station.  But if you're caught on the way, you'll end up as lunch.  So, tread carefully Space Ranger... and pray you don't taste too delicious.

Gameplay Abstract

Players take on the role of characters moving from a crash site location to an abandoned ecology station using point to point movement.  The first player to reach the ecology station is the winner.  As players move their pawns through locations, they must roll a die to avoid detection by alien monsters represented by tokens.  If detected, they must fight.  Individual players use characters with individual strengths and weaknesses and player powers, helping them avoid or defeat monsters.  Each round, events on cards cause more monsters to spawn and regulate monster movement around the game board.

Additional Information

This game is an entry to the contest Sneaky Sci Fi Game Design Contest.

From the flyer: "Children love to play this familiar 'make believe milkman or milkmaid' game. they can make their own deliveries and collections or even run their own dairy business."

The game components are beautifully crafted. Six wooden enameled milk bottles fit neatly inside of the sturdy steel wire carrier container or a red wooden carrier in later editions.

The game was first published in the late 1930's.

Cage is a finite, omnidirectional Checkers variant.  The 10x10 board is initially set up as shown in the figure.  The checkers jump orthogonally in any direction, and the direction can change during multiple jumps.

Cage is a game of annihilation.  The game must end, and when it does, there will remain at most one color of checkers on the board, guaranteed.  One unique feature of Cage is that you can jump off the board, removing both the capturing and captured checkers.

Tensions have been high with the alien "bug" races of the galaxy – the Zothren – and your ship has crash landed on the planet Hive IV, one of the more renegade "bug" planets. You quickly set up perimeter force fields and begin surveying the surrounding terrain for debris from your ship, only to find it scattered everywhere. Then you see them – at first only a few "bug" scouts, but then the numbers begin to increase all around you: archers, slashers, and even the monstrous brutes. This is more than a scouting party; this is a war party! They begin to attack the shields as the crew starts to retrieve debris. The SOS has been sent and a ship in the sector has responded, but can it get to you before the "bugs" overwhelm your crew? Can you repair parts of the ship and use it as a defense? Can you repair the hull and fire up the engine to lift off? It's all in the hands of the crew – your hands.

In Alien Uprising, the player crew must either hold off the Zothren attacks until the rescue ship arrives, or repair the ship and lift off from the hostile planet before being destroyed. To achieve either of these goals, the crew must work together, using their unique skills and chosen actions to perform a number of tasks, defend themselves, and retrieve and repair equipment and the ship.

To establish the actions available each turn, the first player rolls custom dice, then each player chooses an action for the turn, starting with the first player. The available actions include combat, engineering, reload/recharge first aid, scout, and wild; the dice also have an alien icon that shows the speed of the enemy while limiting the actions that players have available to them. Players also have unique character skills, and the game can be set to higher levels of difficulty for more experienced players.

An 18xx game in the first state of Brazil, namely Bahia (BA).

Main characteristics:

Existence of 9 privates railways companies and 1 state-owned company;
Cost for construction of trails;
State incentives for building trails in part of the map;
Possibility of issue shares by railways companies;
Possibility of obtaining loans by railways companies;
Possibility of entry of state-owned company in the game.

Summary of privately held companies:

Grant-court registries - which prevents railways companies from other players build tracks in a round of operations;
Water and sanitation company - turns a town into city;
Contract for sale of agricultural products from other states - adds financial value of the routes that connect certain cities off map to the port cities;
Fundraising for the Estrada de Ferro Bahia ao São Francisco (Railway Bahia to San Francisco) - gives an issue of that railway company to the buyer of this title;
Contract of supply for mining - adds financial value of the routes linking the city of Lençois to another city;
Shipping company of the Velho Chico - only generates dividends;
Construction company - decreases the cost of construction on lands that have rivers and mountains, aand might enable the construction of one extra track in a round of operations.

The Four Courts stumbled out of the gate (see the review "5 players enter the 4 Courts") and has been entirely rewritten. Progress and links to the new rules can be found in the thread "The Four Courts rebuilt" in the News section below.

A Swedish historical trivia game. Translated from the homepage:

"Den Svenska Myllan is a historical quiz. It contains more than 7200 questions and answers.

Questions about the Swedes adventures from Antiquity to the Present. Sometimes you need to know about names and events, others times you use your logic.

Rules, game pieces, dice and dice points (money) are included. The playing field measuring 42x42 cm."

A simple but deep solo game played with pen and grid paper.

Starting from an initial cross pattern of 36 marks, score one point for each mark you can add to the pattern that can be joined with existing marks into a non-overlapping line of five.

You are a "CEO" of a multinational company. Your objective is to "transfer" money from the company account to your private "retirement" account on the Cayman Islands. You fly around the game board in your company jet, carrying a well-stuffed moneybag - but the money isn’t yours.. yet. 
As a serious and highly paid "CEO" you have a lot of chores; hiring a new secretary, whose business qualifications spring from her weeklong experience as a Hooters waitress, convincing the SEC that a couple of late night phone calls do not qualify as insider trading, but are simply a question of friendly talk between collegues, and maintaining your expensive friendship with the local politicians. Of course you also have to be on top of the latest news from the various business' you are involved in, which means chatting up other "CEO's" on luxury cruises. On your way, you encounter the chance to do alittle trading, spend the Company's money on luxury items and maybe have a run-in with the IRS or the SEC. So before you get to fly to Cayman, your moneybag may have inflated or deflated – or you may even be forced to exchange your moneybag with another "CEO".

You are ready to retire (have won the game) when you have put away 150 Million on your private Cayman Islands account.

Three-Card Monte is played one of two ways.  The first method is a children's game in which three cards or objects are laid out face-up.  The cards or objects are then turned face down and scrambled.  The challenge is then to pick out where one of the objects is now positioned.  It's flipped over and the guess is either correct or not.

Variations of this "honest" version are now commonly shown on the big screens of sporting events.

The "confidence" version of Three-Card Monte actually uses 4 cards.  The dealer uses a palming technique to make a card switch, so that the player can't find the correct card.  This method is a rigged game, which often involves the use of a shill to create the illusion the game can be won.

The great powers of eary modern Europe strive for asendency.  Playing country, action, and number cards into various types of melds allows control of a nation, and a chance to industrialize it, through such occurences as war, marriage, alliances. Victory points are awarded for taking control through various means, whoever gets the most points wins.  In addition to a board with spaces for each of 15 countries, there is a custom card deck, and you'll need tokens/markers/chips: unique color for each player to show control, common set for victory points, common set of industry markers.

Get set for a great trip across the U.S.A.! You don't have to worry about what to bring or what to wear. So don't drag out the backpacks or knapsacks, and forget about the plane, train, and bus tickets. You won't even need a driver's license. All you will need for the journey is THE ACROSS THE USA GAME book and a few playful, game-loving friends.

With this great game you'll travel from coast to coast, exploring all fifty states and discovering all sorts of interesting info about this wonderful land of ours. You'll find out about national parks and rivers, famous monuments and landmarks, prominent people, state capitals, flowers, and birds - tons of terrific trivia. When your cross-country game is finished, you will have had a fun-filled time from sea to shining sea - and what better souvenir of an unforgettable trip!

- from inside cover

This game was sold as a slim staple-bound book. The map gameboard is on the center pages, with a list of basic facts about each US state on the backs of the gameboard pages. The surrounding pages contain a total of 32 punch-out trivia cards, each with 8 questions on the front and 8 answers on the back. The rules are inside the back cover. Players must provide their own playing pieces and a die.

- user description

From the box: The ultimate stock car racing trivia board game for race fans coast to coast.

Players answer stock car racing trivia questions to move off Pit Road, onto the Track and around to the Finish and Victory Lane.

User Summary:

Of Armies and Hordes is a fantasy mass combat miniatures system from Ganesha Games, following in the footsteps of its successful fantasy skirmish miniatures system, Song of Blades and Heroes.  Of Armies and Hordes allows players to enact large-scale fantasy battles with 15mm or 25/28mm miniatures, with some similarities (such as Quality and Combat Ratings) to the skirmish rules.

Here is a link to a preview of the Army Builder.

A trivia game about the municipality of Reykjanesbær in Iceland. The questions come in three levels of difficulty making this an easier game for younger / less knowledgable players than many trivia games.

Fantasy Chess is a blend of Traditional Chess and miniatures or role-playing game mechanics where you can co-occupy squares and use dice to determine capture outcomes.

Develop new strategies and alter old ones as you experience familiar chess from a whole new angle.

Traditional King, Queen, Bishop, Knight, Rook, Pawn pieces that move and check the same as traditional chess, but may move through their own ranks, carry pieces, fight for squares (with dice and statistic sheet) and MORE!

Start off with the basic game that teaches how to co-occupy squares (you can have up to three of your own pieces in square) and how to fight for the square (attack the enemy piece using two six sided die against your own dexterity.  If you inflict damage, it lowers the enemy piece's life points.)  If several pieces are in a combat square, they all get an attack.  If it doesn't resolve in one swing each, then combat is continued in the next person's turn.  This means that you can send in re-inforcements.  Each piece class has different dexterity and hit points and some have armor.  All of this is listed on an easy to read stat sheet with bubbles to fill in for damage.

Check is handled in traditional style of check and checkmate.  But there are times when you can actually go head to head with the king in his square and check mate him.

The advanced game includes 4 more rules:

    Withdrawal (escaping from a combat square)
    Healing (Bishops and Queens can heal damaged pieces)
    Forced Retreat (Queens can kick other pieces out of her square)
    Carrying (Knights can carry a pawn or a bishop and Rooks can carry anything except another rook or the king)


In Advanced Tournament Games, winning pieces are declared veteran and they go up a rank either getting more hit points, do more damage or improve dexterity.

Fantasy Chess has the capacity for 4 player games.
Bump two Fantasy Chess boards next to each other and play ally with your partner with full use of both boards as you try to checkmate your opponents.

This can even be expanded into a 5+ player game by either bumping more boards together or having a Game Master who can run some home rule creature pieces as interference or aid to the two main players.  Try putting two rows of squares as a forest between the two boards.

A Chess game where your Knights can charge from Castles, Bishops can heal the injured, Six piece battles can be fought in a square, and you can bludgeon a King to death!

You can obtain Fantasy Chess® from the official website:  www.shadowhex.com or at [www.kickstarter.com/projects/869058411/fantasy-chess-a-fight-for-the-square-chess-variant] until 7 Nov 2011.

A game of starship-based combat and exploration with a variable board of planets and empty space.  Mission, event, equipment and personnel cards are dealt to the planets, and players use their starcraft to travel amongst them, executing missions for the currency used to purchase upgrades to ship and crew, and to earn Fame points.  Game is won when a certain amount of Fame points are collected.

Gasp! is a chaotic, extremely interactive trick-taking game for the Basic Decktet, a handful of its suited tokens and 2-5 players. Players are likely to gasp in astonishment as they watch their fortunes change with alarming frequency and rapidity.

One token in the reigning suit is awarded after each hand and the winner will be the first player to acquire 2 tokens in each of the Decktet’s 6 suits.

Traffic Jam - A zany gridlock game of limited strategy and outrageous bumping and blocking fun.
If you can avoid the patrolling policement and dodge your fellow drivers you have a chance of winning the game. It sounds easy... but players become ruthless as the intersection grows more more congested. One minuted you may be on the verge of winning and the next ... your card is bumped back to the start.
(Back of box)

A simple roll and move game, in which you get questions about the difference between being a follower of the Nazi Party or the Swedish Democrats.

Published in Faktum #95.

Warlocks of the Dark Star is a strategic space wargame pitting the eponymous Warlocks against a group called the Technoids or Techlongs (the rules use both names). The Technoids, as suggested by their name, use technology, while the Warlocks use magic.

The basic system is not especially complicated but there is a fair amount of chrome. For example, the Warlock player receives magic points which can be used to build new units and create effects (such as moving a star system). The Technoid player can't create new units but can scavenge the wrecks of old ones.

At the start of the game, the Warlock player chooses an alien race to play (some of which have special powers) and chooses a home system and colonies, along with a decoy race; all of this information is kept secret. The object of the game for the Technoid player is to find and destroy the Warlocks' systems.

This game should not be confused with Warriors of the Dark Star: The Age of the Neutron Wars.

In ASMV, players 'invest' in the construction of connected regions, while attempting to predict their final size, sabotage opponents' plans, and squeeze into the spaces left behind.

Each turn, a player uses one of their own number tiles, and a color chip from a common supply.  Most often, they will place both in an empty space on the board, subject only to the restriction that they may not create a connected region of a single color containing two or more tiles showing the same number.  Alternatively, a player may remove one color chip from the game, and place their number tile face down on an empty space, preventing it from being part of any colored region.  At the end of the game, every connected region has at most one number tile correctly describing the number of color chips composing that region:  the owner of each such number tile scores its face value in points.

(description provided by designer)

From the rule book:

"How to Play:  Each player is dealt 25 cards by the dealer.  Cards are placed one-at-a-time in an empty slot in the card tray to make 10 poker hands, five across and five deep.  Once placed, that cards cannot be moved.  When each player has filled his/her card tray, players bet on each of the ten hands to win points."

The winner is the first player to score 100 points.

In The Networks, you and your opponents are new television networks, and you need new programming. For this, you’ll need Shows, Stars, and Ads.

Shows need Stars and Ads. Stars give you bonus viewers (points), and Ads give you extra money. You’ll need everything you can get; you'll have a small amount of resources and time, and you must grab the latest hot show before your opponents.

And some Stars will give their best effort only if you put them on in the proper conditions. For example, some Stars only want to be put on dramas. Other Stars want to be the only Star on the show. And your Ads will give you the most money only if you put them on in the correct time slot.

Finally, Shows age and viewers lose interest, so you have to keep your line-up fresh by canceling shows and sending them into reruns. Fortunately, you can get viewers from your reruns, and you'll get bonuses if you get a lot of shows of the same genre throughout the game.

If you need a special push, Network Cards can give you special powers — but will a Network Card be better than another action? You'll have to make that call.

The player with the most viewers after five seasons wins!
